intro: Bugula montana, commonly known as the mountain bugula, is a species of marine bryophyte belonging to the class Bugulophyceae. It is characterized by its erect, branching thallus that often forms dense mats on rocky substrates in shallow coastal waters. The plant exhibits a complex life cycle involving both sexual and asexual reproduction, with the production of spores and vegetative propagules. Its structure consists of a central axis with lateral branches, and it is typically found in temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. Bugula montana plays a role in marine ecosystems by providing habitat for small invertebrates and contributing to benthic biodiversity.
